snippet.textDisplay:
I hope that Bill Gates is aware that most of the CO2 emissions aren't actually from consumers; they're from the companies that said consumers buy from, particularly oil and gas companies as well as power companies that specialize in the burning of fossil fuels. Sure, if every single person on the planet went on to lower their CO2 emissions, we would probably see some sort of small progress, but in reality, until giant companies and corporations realize that global warming is an issue for this generation and not the next, they won't be any the wiser until it's too late.

TL:DR
Big companies produce most CO2, as a single person you can't do squat about it.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay:
3:57 I think it's a stretch to say in an rather off hand way that the operation of an electric car produces much lower levels of CO2 than a gas powered one.

It would surprise me if you haven't taken into account the source of the electricity used for such cars, but I have to assume that's the case!

More than 64% of electricity in the US is generated by coal, natural gas or other fossil fuels. And though the carbon footprint of these different methods is different, and though this means that the remaining 36% of electricity will be from renewable energy, this all still means that your statement must be wrong. Especially since the renewable energy carbon footprint, though lower than fossil fuels, is certainly not zero.

Here's an interesting article about it https://www.investors.com/politics/editorials/electric-cars-co2-emissions-global-warming/
snippet.textOriginal:
3:57 I think it's a stretch to say in an rather off hand way that the operation of an electric car produces much lower levels of CO2 than a gas powered one.

It would surprise me if you haven't taken into account the _source_ of the electricity used for such cars, but I have to assume that's the case! 

More than 64% of electricity in the US is generated by coal, natural gas or other fossil fuels. And though the carbon footprint of these different methods is different, and though this means that the remaining 36% of electricity will be from renewable energy, this all still means that your statement must be wrong. Especially since the renewable energy carbon footprint, though lower than fossil fuels, is certainly not zero.

Here's an interesting article about it https://www.investors.com/politics/editorials/electric-cars-co2-emissions-global-warming/

snippet.textDisplay:
Good. Now let's find out just about how many hundreds of tonnes it takes to produce one single windmill in the renewable wind farms? Including production, transportation, and setting it up. And also replacement parts.

Also I bet most out there dont know that we get our electricity from steam. The easiest and more effective way to produce heat to boil water and turn the steam turbine is coal.

The amount of CO2 to produce 1 windmill would take a few years of electricity production from a coal plant.

Keep that in mind.

snippet.textDisplay:
Yeah got some bad news and good news. The amount of man hours we get from a barrel of oils is so high that nothing short of aliens coming and giving us space technology will cause us to stop using it. So it’s not “should we” or “should we not” use fossil fuels, it’s “how much would you like to be taxed” to use those fossil fuels. The good news is the the greatest green house has is.... wait for it clouds... which is over 70% and we are actually in a carbon “drought” compared to prehistoric times. Sooo the Earth will actually probably become more vibrant with plant life as carbon increases, the “data” linking carbon levels to global temperatures is very questionable and most of the increases in temperature in the past 10,000 years is most likely because, we are coming out of an ice age... So most of climate change is mass hysteria used to scare people who don’t research things for themselves.

Now pollution is an actually problem, and the best thing you can do on a personal level is try to buy products produced in countries with goo environment regulations (aka not China) and try to get things repaired instead on buying something new.

P.S. oh and my personal pet peeve is. Make sure your McDonald’s trash and cigarettes butts end up in a landfill and not my ditch..
snippet.textOriginal:
Yeah got some bad news and good news. The amount of man hours we get from a barrel of oils is so high that nothing  short of aliens coming and giving us space technology will cause us to stop using it. So it’s not “should we” or “should we not” use fossil fuels, it’s “how much would you like to be taxed” to use those fossil fuels. The good news is the the greatest green house has is.... wait for it clouds... which is over 70% and we are actually in a carbon “drought” compared to prehistoric times. Sooo the Earth will actually probably become more vibrant with plant life as carbon increases, the “data” linking carbon levels to global temperatures is very questionable and most of the increases in temperature in the past 10,000 years is most likely because, we are coming out of an ice age... So most of climate change is mass hysteria used to scare people who don’t research things for themselves.

Now pollution is an actually problem, and the best thing you can do on a personal level is try to buy products produced in countries with goo environment regulations (aka not China) and try to get things repaired instead on buying something new. 

P.S. oh and my personal pet peeve is. Make sure your McDonald’s trash and cigarettes butts end up in a landfill and not my ditch..

snippet.textDisplay:
At around 5:40 you start going down a rabbit hole. Getting energy from renewables doesn’t cut your emissions to zero. Solar’s footprint break even point is about 200% past its longevity point. Wind requires fossil backup. Hydro requires massive flood plain. Only nukes have a decent footprint Q-point, provided the steel and concrete are made from ultra leading edge processes.

More germain is the fact that it’s not the 3billion ppl in industrialized nations we need to worry about. It’s the 5billion that want a decent standard of living but can’t cope with the insanely front loaded cost and technical savvy required to build renewable energy infra. These ppl will be using coal and natural gas to get off cow dung.

We got rich off fossil. We’re trying to keep them down by reducing fossil. Until we can deliver clean cheap non-fossil, we need to shut up.
snippet.textOriginal:
At around 5:40 you start going down a rabbit hole. Getting energy from renewables doesn’t cut your emissions to zero. Solar’s footprint break even point is about 200% past its longevity point. Wind requires fossil backup. Hydro requires massive flood plain. Only nukes have a decent footprint Q-point, provided the steel and concrete are made from ultra leading edge processes.

More germain is the fact that it’s not the 3billion ppl in industrialized nations we need to worry about. It’s the 5billion that want a decent standard of living but can’t cope with the insanely front loaded cost and technical savvy required to build renewable energy infra. These ppl will be using coal and natural gas to get off cow dung.

We got rich off fossil. We’re trying to keep them down by reducing fossil. Until we can deliver clean cheap non-fossil, we need to shut up.

snippet.textDisplay: The scale puts carbon emission in perspective. I would love to see more comparisons in a follow up!  Bill and Melinda Gates are remarkable,  sharing their wealth to make a difference. We should all consider donating to a charity we admire, in proportion to what we can afford. A $20 donation is tax deductible and would only mean 4 less coffees, in a first world country!  We should also vote for politicians who are aware that global warming is an issue.

snippet.textDisplay:
You know, I really want to stop driving vehicles. I really hate driving.


No not because it hurts the environment (although that's always at the back of my mind every time I have to drive for half an hour just to cash a check or buy some more Oreos, and then have to use the check I just cashed to afford the gas and Oreos), but because it's so expensive and stressful.


The only time I would ever really want to drive, ideally, in a perfect world, is when I have to travel through the African savanna or through a hell world from Warhammer 40K. I mean the Australian outback.
snippet.textOriginal:
You know, I really want to stop driving vehicles. I really hate driving.


No not because it hurts the environment (although that's always at the back of my mind every time I have to drive for half an hour just to cash a check or buy some more Oreos, and then have to use the check I just cashed to afford the gas and Oreos), but because it's so expensive and stressful.


The only time I would ever really want to drive, ideally, in a perfect world, is when I have to travel through the African savanna or through a hell world from _Warhammer 40K._ I mean the Australian outback.

snippet.textDisplay:
Researchers at the University of Oxford found that cutting meat and dairy products from your diet could reduce an individual's carbon footprint from food by up to 73 per cent. The new study, published in the journal Science, is one of the most comprehensive analyses to date into the detrimental effects farming can have on the environment and included data on nearly 40,000 farms in 119 countries.

The findings reveal that meat and dairy production is responsible for 60 per cent of agriculture’s greenhouse gas emissions, while the products themselves providing just 18 per cent of calories and 37 per cent of protein levels around the world.

Animal Agriculture has to go.
snippet.textOriginal:
Researchers at the University of Oxford found that cutting meat and dairy products from your diet could reduce an individual's carbon footprint from food by up to 73 per cent. The new study, published in the journal Science, is one of the most comprehensive analyses to date into the detrimental effects farming can have on the environment and included data on nearly 40,000 farms in 119 countries.

The findings reveal that meat and dairy production is responsible for 60 per cent of agriculture’s greenhouse gas emissions, while the products themselves providing just 18 per cent of calories and 37 per cent of protein levels around the world.

Animal Agriculture has to go.

snippet.textDisplay: But plastics are way more immediately harmful than CO2. The average person consumes a credit card's worth of microplastics every week, how do you think that affects your body? Microplastics fuck with your hormones, and they're found in nearly all food now. Meanwhile global warming still hasn't caused New York City to sink into the ocean like Al Gore said, and climate change prediction models continue to be wildly wrong and alarmist. If you want to be environmentally-minded then our earth being infested with plastics which won't degrade for hundreds of years is way more of a problem.
snippet.textOriginal: But plastics are way more immediately harmful than CO2. The average person consumes a credit card's worth of microplastics every week, how do you think that affects your body? snippet.textDisplay:
Correction: an electric vehicle powered by renewables still produces CO2. You need to take into account the carbon footprint of manufacturing the renewable energy source. The longer the lifespan and the lower the maintenance, the lower your gCO2/kWh ratio is.

IIRC, Hydro power is the worst CO2 producer of all renewables.
snippet.textOriginal:
